1.text:
Hey everyone, I'm Hayze of Armoured Brownies
and today I shall be walking you through how

5.text:
to
make your own prosthetic half mask for Cosplay,

7.text:
LARP, or whatever kinky thing you're into.
I recorded this live on my stream, hence the

12.text:
overlay, so forgive that.
But I went into a lot more detail there than

15.text: I can do here, unless you have 3hours to spare,

19.text:
Also, don't forget, if you like this, found
it useful or interesting and would like to

24.text:
see more like, comment, subscribe
& maybe even share if you have a friend who

29.text:
may find it useful. It makes me more likely
to

32.text:
For this sculpt we start with our armature,
here I have a plaster cast of a friends face,

36.text:
but you can totally use a normal polystyrene
head.

39.text:
But make sure you get the 17" heads, and also
that you take in account that the lower half

44.text:
of
the face is narrower and shorter than a normal

46.text:
head.
Since we're working with a real face here,

48.text:
we can be pretty tight with our tolerances.
For a half mask like this it's less of an issue.

53.text:
Our first task is to lay down the foundations
over the face cast.

57.text:
This is a face cast I did a few weeks ago
of a victim and friend of mine.

60.text:
The doing that may be posted as a tutorial video
as well in future, so stay tuned.

66.text:
Whilst we're building up the clay we need
to plan out how this mask is going to work

71.text:
on your face
Our biggest worry is that you can't sculpt

74.text:
what isn't there. This ghoul has no nose,
but whoever is wearing it

78.text:
almost certainly does, unless they're super
dedicated.

82.text:
To create the illuesion that the wearer doesn't
have a nose we need to build out the entire

86.text:
face, cheeks, nose, brow
which brings where the nose would be forward,

91.text: that I can then effectively it chop off!

93.text:
So far we can just use our fingers, at no point
whilst doing the basic foundation and anatomy

98.text:
do we need a tool,
your fingers are perfectly fine for doing

101.text:
these large, broad strokes and shapes.
Just be sure to keep a little a pot of water

104.text:
besside you to keep your fingers moist, otherwise
the clay will end up sticking to them rather

109.text:
Whilst building up the anatomy we're making
sure to leave the eyes clear, as it is possible

113.text:
to cover them up
sculpt them out, but since this is suppose

116.text:
to use the wearers real eyes, future you will
thank you for not covering

119.text:
them up here.
Leaving larger eyes in the mask will make

122.text:
it more comfortable to wear, but the less
of your

125.text:
human face will end up covered by the final
product.

128.text:
Once we have an anatomy we're happy with,
I took a tool and just scraped away the top

132.text:
of the nose until I found the
real nose underneath, and this gave me the

136.text:
limit that I can work with, so I have an area
to sculpt around.

140.text:
We build it up a tiny bit, just to give us
a little be of leeway though.

143.text:
Now we start sketching out some of the larger
details, like the edge of the nose bone, which

147.text:
I'm doing here with a
gouging tool, it's basiclaly a sculpting tool

150.text:
with a spoon on it that removes a lot of material
as you go along drag it along.

154.text:
And now have a base anatomy we're happy
with, you can take as long as you like over

157.text:
this, making sure the cheek
bones are where they should be, the jowels

160.text:
line up and the brown isn't too overhanging.
So, using our fingers and plenty of water

164.text:
I go over the surface and smooth it all down,
leveling it out and giving us

168.text:
an even surface to work with.
There is such a tool as a rake, which can

171.text:
be used to smooth clay surfaces but this doesn't
need to be that exact.

176.text:
Now we can start on what is more traditionally
thought of, as the sculpt.

179.text:
The nose is one of the harder parts of thise
sculpt, so here we're just playing around

184.text:
with it, trying to get a shape and feel that
we're happy with,

186.text:
but we'll come back to it later once it's
dried out a little and gotten a bit firmer,

192.text:
anyway.
Now we move on to more broad strokes of anatomy,

196.text:
such as the defining of the eyebrows and
where the jowls would be, this helps layout

200.text:
the nose and the edges of our lips, and even
do a philtrum, as

205.text:
we're basically laying out the look of any
normal human before we ghoulfy her.

210.text:
So, most ghouls have lots of pitting, underneath
their cheek bones, and around their face.

215.text:
Because even though they have
soft tissue, they have lots of flesh missing

218.text:
as they're basically radiation zombies.
Thankfully because we have built up the surface

223.text:
quite nicely from the face, we've got a lot
of leeway for taking big chewy chunks out!

228.text:
Once again we're using our scooping spoon
like tool that takes away lots of material,

232.text:
and then moving on
to using a silicone tool for the edges, as

235.text:
it's fairly soft, and doesn't remove too much
material at once so you can be a bit

238.text:
more careful about it and get smoother, less
sudden edges around your facial pits.

244.text:
We need to try and be careful about the amount
of water that we're putting on our sculpt,

247.text:
as the more water we keep putting on the sculpt
the softer the clay is and harder it becomes

251.text:
to put details in. It means more time is needed
to leave it to cool down and dry out, to become

257.text:
leatherier and resistant.
Allowing more accurate details to be added.

261.text:
Once you get experienced with using your perfered
medium, for me it's this water based clay,

265.text:
WED, you can use quirks like
this to you advantage.

267.text:
We're going to put some tight wrinked texture
around the eyes here.

270.text:
For this we use a narrow sculpting tool to
cut lots of little, few milimetre deep channels

275.text:
along the edges of the eyes, all the way around,
making sure

277.text:
we're not removing too much clay at once.
This may look unnatural at first, but we're

281.text:
leaving the high ridges of drier clay that
we then, using our fingers and a generous

286.text:
dose of water, smooth down lightly. The water
will turn some of the surface to mud and we

291.text:
spread it around a touch, it'll fill the
channels we've just cut, but not entirely,

296.text:
leaving a pleasing, smooth, natural looking
tight set of wrinkles.

300.text:
This will also help blend it to your wearers
eyes.

302.text:
You can reapeat this a few times until you
have an effect you're happy with, but you

306.text: may need to leave it to dry before tryng again.

308.text:
Now, back to doing pitting and scarring.
We actually end up taking a bit of the material

312.text:
we scooped off and using it to build up extra
scarred parts, almost like veins.

316.text:
Here we can blend it into the mask quite nicely
with our fingers and lots of water.

319.text:
May be noticing a theme here.
You just use your fingers, pinching along

324.text:
the edges of the clay strip with some of water
to blend all in, then follow it up by defining

328.text:
it with a solid tool until
we're happy with our result.

331.text:
So, we are going to start doing some burn
texture.

335.text:
We're going to use these two spoon backed
sculpting tools, as they allow us to tap in

339.text:
dentsto the skin, were it's gone melty,
creating

342.text:
indentations and rehealed parts.
We're got to make sure we keep our tool quite

346.text:
dry and the surface we're working on is also
pretty firm.

348.text:
It doens't matter if we're pulling out little
feelers of clay as well go as that'll just

354.text:
add a little bit of extra texture.  But you don't want to be pulling out big chunks.
Just doing a few rows of this at a time, and then with

361.text:
a little bit of water on our fingers we smooth
it down ever so lightly, blending it down

366.text:
to a natural looking surface and there we
go, we have a nice burned skin texture.

371.text:
The higher edges of skin parts, like the cheekbones
and brows should probably be left a little

376.text:
smoother, or smoothed out a little
heavier with your fingure so they have some

381.text: but are a little smoother than the deeper parts of the face.

384.text:
We can add some more sever looking scars by
using the tools to pucker out flesh in circles

388.text:
or shapes, and create some nice looking slashes
by scarping lines out

392.text:
of the clay and patting it down later and
blending it into our burned flesh texture.

396.text:
So much of this sculpt is creating shapes,
then blending it into a natural looking skin

400.text: texture with water and our fingers, and maybe brushes and sponges.

404.text:
To bring out some of these more serious scars
on the face we pucker out the flesh with the

409.text:
side of a sculpting tool, to give some
depth to skin where different layers of skin

412.text: have peeled back or be ripped off.

415.text: We now repeat this for the whole face.

420.text:
This is our hour mark.
You can see how I've been blending the scarring

425.text:
effect with the large welts and pitting on
the face.

428.text:
This may look almost done, but there's lots
of getting it clean, pulling it together and

431.text:
finishing effects to go.
For reference this sculpt took a total of

435.text:
an hour and a half, so this two thirds though.
Half of the delays for finishing it was waiting

439.text:
for parts of it to dry out enough that I could
put the more detailed effects on them.

444.text:
Because as I say, with this clay you can vary
it's resistance by keeping track of it's moisture levels.

448.text:
My last job really,
was the nose.

450.text:
This takes a lot of the techniques already
used and puts them to use in a more compact

454.text:
detailed setting.
Using thin tools to create the difference

457.text:
between the skin and nose bone, and then creating
a deeper texture of ridges suggesting

461.text:
internal nose structure around the centre
of the nose. We do the ridges much like we

465.text:
did the wrinkles around the eyes
only with wider channels cut with a different tool.

470.text:
And that is quite likley, finished.
Though, there are still a few parts that I

475.text:
don't like, but, just some liberal use of
water and brushes and fingers can blend them

479.text:
it
better and hide them well enough.

481.text:
It's all just making it look more and more
organic! And you can pick out all of these

487.text: wonderful subtle details when you paint it.

492.text:
There we go!
We have a sculpt.

494.text:
It won't look quite right until it's dried
properly.

497.text: But that's a completed, speed sculpted ghoul.

500.text:
From the side it's a little obvious where
the wearers nose goes, but any other angle

505.text:
it gives a great effect of the noses soft
tissue

510.text:
Join us next time for the mould making for
this sculpt.

514.text: Thank you for joining me!Please Like, Subscribe and Comment!

518.text:
Please Like, Subscribe and Comment!
Also, feedback on these captions would be great.
